item.title: Satellites at Work | Blue Ridge Boost
item.description:
The 2025 challenge focuses on the importance of satellites, their use in daily life (e.g., communication, GPS, and weather forecasting), and the role of AI and robots in space debris cleanup and satellite deployment. Teams are tasked with programming robots to perform missions related to satellites and space debris.

Game Field Overview

  • The game field includes various mission areas such as rocket fuel, launch pad, satellite orbits, space debris, astronauts, and a barrier.
  • Randomization occurs for satellite placement in each round:
    • 4 satellites (out of 5) are placed on the field.
    • 1 satellite is left out each round.
  • Fixed elements (e.g., rocket fuel, space debris, astronauts, and barrier) are always in the same position.

Robot Missions

  1. Fuel the Rocket:
    • Transport rocket fuel from the starting area to the rocket fuel area.
    • Scoring:
      • Completely in the fuel area: 10 points.
      • Partly touching the fuel area: 5 points.
  2. Launch the Rocket:
    • Push the rocket along the rail to simulate a launch into space.
    • Scoring:
      • Rocket beyond 2nd red marker: 15 points.
      • Rocket beyond 1st red marker (but not the 2nd): 5 points.
  3. Collect Satellites and Place Them in Orbits:
    • Identify and transport satellites to their corresponding colored orbits.
    • Scoring:
      • Satellite completely in the correct orbit: 20 points.
      • Satellite partly in any orbit or in the wrong-colored orbit: 5 points.
  4. Collect Space Debris:
    • Bring 3 pieces of space debris back to the start area.
    • Scoring:
      • Each piece touching the start area: 10 points (maximum of 30 points).
  5. Bonus for Astronauts and Barrier:
    • Ensure the astronauts and barrier are not moved or damaged during the mission.
    • Scoring:
      • Each astronaut not moved or damaged: 5 points.
      • Barrier not moved or damaged: 10 points.

Scoring Overview

  • Maximum score per round: 155 points.
  • Missions can be completed in any order.
  • Bonus points are awarded for preserving the astronauts and barrier.
  • Only the highest-scoring satellite in each orbit counts.

Who Should Enroll?

This course is ideal for students aged 8–12 who are interested in robotics, programming, and STEM challenges. No prior robotics experience is required, though familiarity with basic programming concepts is helpful.

item.title: Intermediate Counting And Probabilities | Blue Ridge Boost
item.description:
This course comprehensively explores advanced counting, probability, and combinatorics topics essential for problem-solving in mathematics and related fields. Designed for students with a foundational understanding of mathematics, it emphasizes theoretical concepts and practical problem-solving skills. The course is structured to gradually build expertise, starting with basics and progressing to more complex topics like generating functions, graph theory, and advanced probability.

Summary of Topics

  1. Review of Counting & Probability Basics
    • Counting techniques, probability basics, expected value, Pascal's triangle, binomial theorem, and summation notation.
  2. Sets and Logic
    • Set theory, operations on sets, logical reasoning, truth tables, and quantifiers.
  3. Principle of Inclusion-Exclusion (PIE)
    • Counting with overlapping sets, extending PIE to multiple properties, and solving advanced counting problems.
  4. Constructive Counting and 1-1 Correspondences
    • Constructive approaches to counting, one-to-one correspondences, and clever problem-solving techniques.
  5. Pigeonhole Principle
    • Applications of the pigeonhole principle in basic and advanced combinatorics problems.
  6. Constructive Expectation
    • Calculating expectations constructively, summing expectations, and handling complex expectation problems.
  7. Distributions
    • Distributing items among groups, applying conditions, and solving complex distribution problems.
  8. Mathematical Induction
    • Introduction to induction, basic proofs, and problem-solving with this fundamental technique.
  9. Fibonacci Numbers
    • Properties, problems, formulas, and applications of Fibonacci numbers.
  10. Recursion
    • Understanding recursion, linear recurrences, Catalan numbers, and their applications.
  11. Conditional Probability
    • Basics, notation, harder examples, and real-world applications like the "Let's Make a Deal" problem.
  12. Combinatorial Identities
    • Deriving and applying basic and advanced combinatorial identities.
  13. Events With States
    • State diagrams, random walks, infinite states, and strategy games.
  14. Generating Functions
    • Basics, applications to binomial theorem, distributions, partitions, and Fibonacci numbers.
  15. Graph Theory
    • Definitions, properties, cycles, paths, planar graphs, Eulerian and Hamiltonian paths.

item.title: Advanced Python for Teens | Blue Ridge Boost
item.description:
Advanced Python for Teens builds on foundational Python skills and introduces students to more advanced programming concepts. This course is designed to help students create more powerful and efficient programs by exploring key topics such as functions, strings, data structures, and file input/output operations. Through engaging lessons, hands-on exercises, and creative projects, students will deepen their understanding of Python and develop practical problem-solving skills.

Course Highlights:

  • Functions and Exceptions: Learn how to decompose programs into smaller, reusable components and handle errors effectively.
  • Strings: Master advanced techniques for manipulating and processing text in programs.
  • Data Structures: Explore the creation and manipulation of tuples, lists, grids, and dictionaries to build complex programs.
  • File I/O: Gain the ability to read, write, and process information from text files.

item.title: Mechanical Foundations with REV DUO | Blue Ridge Boost
item.description: The Mechanical Foundations with REV DUO course provides participants with the hands-on skills and knowledge needed to design, build, and maintain robotic systems confidently. Through interactive projects and challenges, students will explore the foundational mechanical principles that drive robotics, such as structure, motion, power transmission, and mechanical advantage. Using the REV DUO building system, participants will gain practical experience assembling and testing robotic components while learning to solve real-world engineering challenges.

item.title: Advanced Python for Tweens | Blue Ridge Boost
item.description:
Through interactive challenges, students help twin baby monkeys reunite by solving coding problems, reinforcing their understanding of Python fundamentals and advanced topics. The course covers essential concepts such as sequencing, loops, conditionals, and functions.

Course Content

  • Basics review
  • Classes: Understanding object-oriented programming to create and manage complex data structures.
  • Input: Interacting with users by receiving and processing input data.
  • String manipulation: Performing operations on text data to modify and analyze it.
  • Advanced data types: Utilizing complex data structures like dictionaries and sets for efficient data management.
  • 2D lists: Working with multi-dimensional arrays to handle grid-based data.
  • Bubble sort: Learning basic sorting algorithms to organize data effectively.

item.title: Anatomy & Physiology | Blue Ridge Boost
item.description:
Dive into the fascinating world of human anatomy with this engaging class focused on the integumentary, muscular, and skeletal systems! Students will explore how these three systems work together to protect, support, and move the body. Through interactive lessons, hands-on activities, and real-world examples, participants will:

  • Integumentary System: Learn about the skin, hair, nails, and glands, and discover how they protect the body, regulate temperature, and enable sensory perception.
  • Muscular System: Examine the three types of muscles (skeletal, smooth, and cardiac) and understand how muscle contractions drive movement, posture, and vital bodily functions.
  • Skeletal System: Uncover the structure and function of bones, joints, and cartilage, and see how the skeleton supports the body, protects vital organs, and enables movement.

By the end of the course, students will gain a deeper understanding of how these systems contribute to overall health and interact to maintain the body’s structure and function. This class is perfect for anyone curious about biology, anatomy, or pursuing a career in healthcare or science!

item.title: Science Challenges | Blue Ridge Boost
item.description:
4-Class Series: Building a Hydraulic System

In these hands-on sessions, teams will design and construct a freestanding hydraulic device capable of lifting a 100g weight at least 30 cm and holding it for 30 seconds. Using only the materials provided, students will explore the practical applications of hydraulic systems while working collaboratively to solve this engineering challenge.

4-Class Series: Origami Glider Relay

In these hands-on events, teams will construct an origami glider (either a Dihedral Magnus Effect glider or a Tumblewing glider) and navigate it through a relay-style obstacle course for the fastest time. Participants must optimize their design during the building phase to ensure their glider performs well in flight. This session emphasizes creativity, precision, and teamwork.

item.title: Science Challenges | Blue Ridge Boost
item.description:
4-Class Series: Building a Rube Goldberg Machine

This engaging 4-class series will guide teams through the process of designing, building, and refining a Rube Goldberg device to create the longest-timed chain reaction. Participants will learn how to incorporate the six simple machines—lever, screw, pulley, wheel and axle, inclined plane, and wedge—into their designs. By the end of the series, teams will be ready to compete in a fun and challenging event that tests their creativity, engineering, and understanding of physics.

item.title: Vision and History | Blue Ridge Boost
item.description:
History of Blue Ridge Boost

During the COVID-19 pandemic, I spent a significant amount of time teaching and helping my children learn, and I discovered that I greatly enjoy teaching young students. This newfound passion led me to quit my Ph.D. program in Computer Science to pursue a degree in teaching at the University of Virginia, and I subsequently launched Blue Ridge Boost.

During the lockdown, Maxwell and Dorina enrolled in various challenging and exciting classes offered by the Center for Talented Youth at Johns Hopkins and The Art of Problem Solving. Despite the quality of the instructors, the lack of face-to-face interaction was a significant drawback.
